docs.title: 1. Next-Generation identity federation
docs.text:
As individual universities and research institutes began using integrated authentication infrastructures for institution-wide services, the demand for more advanced and secure usage emerged. In other words, there is an increasing need to establish an environment where services, such as supercomputers and research infrastructures - whose provision has been discouraged due to security concerns, or whose complex authentication was provided individually - can be accessed through IdP authentication by enabling IdPs to offer robust authentication.

In response to this, GakuNin began researching and developing the n next-Generation identity federation infrastructure. We established the Working Group for Next-Generation Identity Federation and are working toward its realization.

docs.title: 2. Authenticator Assurance Level
docs.text:
As part of this initiative, a policy was established by the Working Group for Next-Generation Identity Federation to operate the GakuNin AAL (Authenticator Assurance Level) standards, which define multi-factor authentication as a stronger authentication method. This policy is implemented with IdPs as the control target. The aim is to implement AAL2, a stronger authentication standard, for services that require a higher level of security.

The AAL2 standards are defined in accordance with NIST SP800-63 and Kantara KIAF1440.

docs.title: 3. What is the Authenticator Registry?
docs.text: In the GakuNin AAL2 standards, it is described that GakuNin should establish and provide an Authenticator Registry for its operation. The Authenticator Registry is a registry that stores information related to GakuNin AAL2-compliant authenticators, with the purpose of providing information to GakuNin-participating IdPs.

docs.title: 4. Benefit of the Authenticator Registry 1 (Reduced Workload)
docs.text:
To accredit and operate GakuNin AAL2, it is necessary to evaluate the large number of authenticators available in the market. However, it is not practical for each GakuNin-participating institution to individually evaluate AAL2 compliance for each authenticator, given the workload and costs involved.

For example, when conducting an evaluation, various factors need to be considered, such as the following:

  1. What type does this authenticator fall under?
  2. Does this authenticator meet the requirements of the GakuNin AAL2 standards?
  3. Is this authenticator single-factor or multi-factor on its own?
  4. What operational issues does this authenticator present?
  5. What security risks does this authenticator pose?

Naturally, this requires a significant amount of work, and in some cases, it may be necessary to hire individuals with specialized knowledge.

We believe that, in terms of reducing workloads and cost-effectiveness, it is rational for GakuNin to evaluate the performance of authenticators, determine whether they meet the AAL2 standards for authentication, and provide an Authenticator Registry that shares and publishes the results.

docs.title: 5. Benefit of the Authenticator Registry 2 (As a Source of Information)
docs.text:
The Authenticator Registry also provides various information related to authenticators.

For example, by providing information about the types and mechanisms of authenticators, GakuNin-participating institutions can use this information to select authenticators that best suit their needs. Additionally, it helps institutions ensure proper operation by understanding security risks and taking appropriate measures. Furthermore, by providing information on how to configure and use the authenticators, GakuNin-participating institutions can streamline implementation and improve operational efficiency.

docs.title: 6. Conclusion
docs.text: Through the Authenticator Registry, we will provide essential information for introducing and operating the AAL2 standards within GakuNin. Additionally, we plan to regularly perform maintenance to ensure that the registry remains a reliable and up-to-date information source.

docs.title: Obtaining a Login Account
docs.text:
To use this system, you will need a dedicated account.

If you are using it for the first time, please follow the link ‘Contact Us Here’ below. Once redirected, sign up for an account by entering your email address, password and name in the ‘Sign Up for an Account’ section on the right side of the screen. The account you create here can be used for inquiries across various services, including GakuNin, the UPKI Digital Certificate Issuing Service and eduroam JP.

docs.title: Inquiry Process
docs.text:
After signing up/logging in, please select the category that best matches your question and submit your inquiry.

You will receive our response via email from: gakunin-jsd_at_nii-auth.atlassian.net. You can also check responses by logging into the system and going to ‘Requests - My Requests’ in the top-right corner.

To reply to a response, you can either reply to the email you received or add a comment to the inquiry in My Requests.

docs.title: Authenticator Description
docs.text:
• A FIDO authenticator is an authenticator designed and manufactured based on specifications established by the FIDO Alliance, and is used when accessing services participating in GakuNin. It falls under categories of Single-Factor and Multi-Factor Cryptographic Software or Cryptographic Device. The authenticator is provided when the user obtains it from a company that distributes FIDO authenticators and carries out the activation process.
    • You can check which authenticators comply with the FIDO specifications on theFIDO Certified Products page.

docs.title: Authenticator Features
docs.text:
• FIDO2 is a specification designed to enable password-less authentication and multi-factor authentication for services. It mainly consists of WebAuthn, a web authentication method, and CTAP, a communication specification. It allows users to use multi-factor authentication securely when accessing services.
    • FIDO UAF is a specification for performing password-less authentication, which allows FIDO authenticators to provide authentication using biometric factors, PINs and security tokens.
    • FIDO U2F is a specification for using physical security keys, primarily through USB or NFC devices, as the second factor of authentication, enabling multi-factor authentication.

docs.title: Authenticator Types
docs.text: Single-Factor and Multi-Factor Cryptographic Software, Single-Factor and Multi-Factor Cryptographic Device

docs.title: Providers
docs.text: Manufacturer of authenticators that design and manufacture according to the specifications of the FIDO Alliance

docs.title: Authentication Factors
docs.text: Biometric-based factors (“something you are”) , Possession-based factors (“something you have”), Knowledge-based factors (“something you know”)

docs.title: Authenticator Description
docs.text: • Google Authenticator is an authenticator that can be used to perform authentication using a One-Time Password (OTP) when accessing services participating in GakuNin. It is an OTP app classified as a Single-Factor OTP device. The authenticator is provided in the form of an app installed on a smartphone, and is made available to users through the iOS and Android app stores by Google.

docs.title: Authenticator Features
docs.text: • An OTP app is an authenticator that generates OTPs that become invalid once used. The user obtains the OTP through a separate channel from the one used to connect to the service. When using an OTP app in GakuNin, the user is required to enter a knowledge-based factor, such as a password, for the first step of authentication, and then enter the OTP generated by the OTP app for the second step of authentication.

docs.title: UPKI Digital Certificate Issuing Service, Client Certificate
Authenticator Description
docs.text: • The UPKI client certificate is an authenticator used when accessing services participating in GakuNin, with the client certificate issued by the UPKI Digital Certificate Issuing Service. The UPKI client certificate is categorized as Single-Factor Cryptographic Software. This authenticator is provided when the user obtains the issued client certificate and installs it on their own device.

docs.title: Authenticator Features
docs.text: • Cryptographic Software is a possession-based authenticator based on a digital certificate, which is used by a specific client to prove their identity to a service.

docs.title: Authenticator Version
docs.text: Compliant with the specification change as of 2023-12-14 (Reference URL: https://certs.nii.ac.jp/news/20231013 )

docs.title: 3.Acknowledgements
docs.text: • We would like to express our sincere gratitude to the members of the FIDO Japan Working Group for their reviews for the publication of this document.

docs.title: 4.Notes
docs.text:
• This document is a translation of the original English text. Please refer to the original English version as needed.
  • The FIDO Alliance distinguishes between passkeys with sync capabilities across multiple devices (synced passkeys) and those that remain on a single device (device-bound passkeys). In this document, the term "passkey" appears to refer to the synced passkeys as defined by the FIDO Alliance. Please bear this in mind.
